speaker: Doctor
text: Good morning, I'm Dr. Agent. Can you please tell me a little bit about yourself and why you're here today?

speaker: Patient
text: I was born a few days ago, and I've been having some trouble since then. My mom says I'm a little different, but she hasn't really been able to take care of me because she didn't go to any doctor visits during her pregnancy.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your chart, and I see that you're a newborn, about a week old. Can you tell me, have you been experiencing any difficulty feeding or having trouble gaining weight since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really feel like eating that much. When I do eat, I get really tired afterwards.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you seem a bit lethargic, can you tell me if you're feeling tired or sleepy more often than usual?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I'm always tired. Even when I'm lying down, I just feel so sleepy.

speaker: Doctor
text: You seem to be responding a bit slowly, can you tell me if you're experiencing any pain or discomfort anywhere in your body?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't feel any pain, but sometimes I get these little spots on my skin that look a bit blue. They don't really hurt, but they're just there.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your chart, it seems like you were a bit premature, is that correct?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I was premature, I was born at term. My mom says I'm just a bit small for my age.

speaker: Doctor
text: You mentioned you were a bit premature, can you tell me how many weeks early you were born?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think I was premature, my mom says I was born right on time.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've also reviewed your chart and noticed that you were born at 28 weeks gestation, which is quite early. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any unusual skin rashes or lesions since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. But I do have some things on my skin that don't look quite right. They're kind of blue and they don't go away when you press on them.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your responses, but I have to say, I'm a bit concerned about your symptoms. Can you tell me if you've had any episodes of blue discoloration around your mouth, nose, or skin since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I have had some of those episodes, and it seems like I get them whenever I'm trying to breathe. They go away after a little while, but they're kind of scary.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see you've been having some trouble feeding. Can you tell me if you've been spitting up or vomiting after feedings?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really spit up, but sometimes I get this feeling like my eyes are all cloudy, like I'm looking through a misty window.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that you're having some trouble feeding and spitting up after meals. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any difficulty breathing or making high-pitched sounds while breathing?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really make any sounds when I breathe, but sometimes it feels like I'm making a really high-pitched noise, like a squeaky toy. It's really quiet, though, so you might not be able to hear it.

speaker: Doctor
text: You've been having trouble breathing and making high-pitched sounds while breathing, that's concerning. Have you been experiencing any pauses in breathing or episodes of not breathing at all?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, sometimes when I'm trying to breathe, it feels like I'm not getting any air, and then it just stops for a second. It's really scary.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've been noticing that you seem a bit fragile, can you tell me if you've been experiencing any episodes of grunting or straining while breathing?

speaker: Patient
text: I grunt a little bit when I breathe, but it's really quiet, like I'm making a little squeak.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your difficulty breathing and grunting episodes. Have you been receiving any oxygen therapy or supplemental oxygen since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. I just get this really loud, high-pitched noise when I try to breathe, and it's really hard to catch my breath.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've noticed that you're having trouble breathing and have been experiencing grunting episodes. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any episodes of apnea, or pauses in breathing, while you're sleeping?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I do get those pauses when I'm sleeping, and it's really scary. It feels like my whole body just freezes up and I can't breathe.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your apnea episodes while sleeping, that's crucial information. Have you been experiencing any episodes of fever or increased temperature since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, my mom says I've just been really cold a lot, even when it's warm in the room.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of your apnea episodes while sleeping and the fact that you've been experiencing a fever. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any seizures or convulsions since birth?

speaker: Patient
text: No, I don't think so. But sometimes when I try to move my eyes, it feels like they're stuck or something, and it's really hard to get them to move.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed your symptoms, and I have to say, I'm getting a bit concerned. Have you had any contact with anyone who has been sick or has a contagious illness recently?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, my mom says she hasn't been around anyone who's sick. But sometimes when I try to hear things, it feels like I'm not really listening to them, like I'm not really hearing anything.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see you've been having trouble breathing and have been experiencing grunting episodes. Have you been experiencing any unusual sounds or murmurs when I listen to your heart with my stethoscope?

speaker: Patient
text: Yes, I think I have been making some strange noises when you listen to my heart. It's kind of a constant sound, like a whisper, and it doesn't seem to change when I move around or breathe.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've taken note of the unusual sounds I heard when I listened to your heart. Can you tell me if you've been experiencing any swelling in your abdomen or any unusual fullness in your tummy?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't think so, my tummy feels pretty normal. But I do feel a bit tight when I cry, like my chest is getting all tight and hard.

speaker: Doctor
text: I've reviewed all the information you've provided, and I must say, it's quite concerning. Can you please hold still for just a moment while I take a closer look at your chest with my stethoscope?
